mainContent.text:
3.2 Logical Reasoning

        Completion requirements
        



Types of Reasoning
If the claim is the building block of all academic writing, then logical reasoning is the mortar that holds the building together.  It is "glue" that helps join together claims with evidence.  Logical reasoning helps
    you to recognize the parts of an argument and their relationships, to make well-supported conclusions, to recognize misunderstandings or points of disagreement, to identify warrants (underlying assumptions), and to anticipate flaws (logical fallacies) in arguments.


Logical reasoning comes in two types: deductive reasoning and inductive reasoning.  Deductive reasoning guarantees the absolute truth of a conclusion. Inductive reasoning is less absolute; it leads to the probability of a conclusion.  The goal of deductive reasoning is to lead to certainty, using a direct and absolute line of reasoning.  The goal of inductive reasoning is to lead to trends, using a likelihood in the line of reasoning.  

Deductive Reasoning: If A equals B, and B equals C, then A is equal to C (absolutely true every time).
Inductive Reasoning: If A is similar to B, and B is similar to C, then A is similar to C (likelihood of similarity but not a guarantee).
Key Words: Deductive reasoning uses very strong language, which makes arguments "air tight," with no exceptions:
    “All…” ; “It must be…” ; “It is true that…” ; “Everyone…” ; “...always…” ; “...never…”

Key Words: Inductive reasoning uses less strong language, which, again, leads to probability and trends:   
    “Most…” ;  “Usually…” ; “Likely…” ; “Probably…” ; “For the most part…” ; "...in most cases..."
Which
one is this, deductive or inductive?  

    "Most humans are right-handed.  I am a human.  Therefore, I am most-likely right-handed." 
 If you said "inductive reasoning," you are correct.  Which words gave it away?  "Most likely?"  Of course!  It is probably the case, but it cannot be an absolute truth.
